title: How to Install an SSD in Your Laptop

steps.title: Purchase the right SSD.
steps.content: Purchase the right SSD. SDD's can come in different sizes and thicknesses. You also need to make sure the drive has the right interface for your laptop (SATA, or IDE). A 2.5-inch, 7 mm thick SATA drive is what is most commonly used in newer laptops. However, thinner laptops may use a 1.8-inch drive (if they can be upgraded at all). Some laptops use a 9.5 mm drive. Consult your laptop's user manual, or the manufacturer's website to make sure you purchase the right SSD for your laptop.

steps.title: Purchase an external enclosure or adapter.
steps.content: Purchase an external enclosure or adapter. This will allow you connect your SSD to your computer via USB during the cloning process. Then after the drive is installed, you can use an external enclosure to turn your old hard drive into an external hard drive.

steps.title: Purchase EDS wrist straps {optional}.
steps.content: Purchase EDS wrist straps {optional}. EDS wrist straps prevent static discharges that can cause permanent damage to your hard drive and other computer parts. If you are not using EDS wrist straps, make sure to ground yourself by touching something metal before you begin working with the hard drives, or the inside of your laptop.

steps.title: Purchase an external hard drive (optional).
steps.content: Purchase an external hard drive (optional). If you have a lot of large folders, it may be useful to purchase an additional external hard drive to backup all your files .

steps.title: Backup your files and free up space.
steps.content: Backup your files and free up space. The SSD you are installing is most likely smaller than the hard drive you currently have installed. If your SSD doesn't have enough space to transfer all your files, backup and delete as much as needed so that you can transfer all the contents of your current drive to the SSD drive. You can backup your files using an external drive, an optical disk, a USB drive, or cloud-based storage like Dropbox , or Google Drive .

steps.title: Press ⊞ Win+X.
steps.content: Press ⊞ Win + X . This will display a list of Windows options you can click.

steps.title: Click Disk Management.
steps.content: Click Disk Management . It's about halfway down the list.

steps.title: Right-click your current hard drive.
steps.content: Right-click your current hard drive. This is the hard drive that has Windows and all your files installed on it. This is usually the "C:" drive.

steps.title: Select Shrink Volume.
steps.content: Select Shrink Volume . It will take a moment to read the drive and see how much space you can shrink the volume by.

steps.title: Type the number of megabytes (MB) you want to shrink.
steps.content: Type the number of megabytes (MB) you want to shrink. Make sure the total size after the shrink is smaller than the SSD drive. If you have a 250 GB SSD, the total size after the shrink will need to be smaller than 250,000 MB (500,000 for a 500 GB SSD).

steps.title: Click Shrink.
steps.content: Click Shrink . During the shrink process, your current drive so that it's smaller, and leave the rest of the space as unallocated.

steps.title: Go to https://www.easeus.com/backup-software/tb-free.html in a web browser.
steps.content: Go to https://www.easeus.com/backup-software/tb-free.html in a web browser. This website allows you to download a free version of EaseUS ToDo Backup, which will allow you to clone your current disk drive to your SSD. If you purchased a data transfer kit that comes with its own cloning software, go ahead and use that.

steps.title: Click Free Download.
steps.content: Click Free Download . It's the large blue button in the center of the page.

steps.title: Click Download Now.
steps.content: Click Download Now . It's the large blue button at the top of the page.

steps.title: Type your email address in the text field and click Submit.
steps.content: Type your email address in the text field and click Submit . Your email address is required in order to download the software.

steps.title: Click Download EaseUS ToDo Backup Free.
steps.content: Click Download EaseUS ToDo Backup Free . It's the link at the top of the window.

steps.title: Navigate to and click "tb_free.exe".
steps.content: Navigate to and click "tb_free.exe". By default, all downloaded files can be found in your "Download" folder.

steps.title: Select your language and click Ok.
steps.content: Select your language and click Ok . Use the drop-down menu to select a language. "English" will be the default language.

steps.title: Click Next.
steps.content: Click Next . It's in the lower-right corner.

steps.title: Click Accept.
steps.content: Click Accept . This will indicate that you agree to the terms of conditions.

steps.title: Select an install location and click Next.
steps.content: Select an install location and click Next . Click the "browse" button to select a different install location, if you want the install location to be different from the default.

steps.title: Click Next.
steps.content: Click Next . Make sure the checkbox next to "Create a desktop icon" is checked so that you can easily find and launch the program.

steps.title: Select a backup folder location and click Next.
steps.content: Select a backup folder location and click Next . You can use your current drive, or select an external hard drive.

steps.title: Uncheck any offers and click Next.
steps.content: Uncheck any offers and click Next . You may be presented with a couple of offers before the software installs. It is recommended that you uncheck those offers and click "Next".

steps.title: Click Finish.
steps.content: Click Finish . One the install is complete, click "Finish".

steps.title: Place the SSD drive in an external enclosure.
steps.content: Place the SSD drive in an external enclosure. The external enclosure is a device that you place your SSD in. Make sure you are wearing your EDS straps before handling your SSD. If you don't have EDS straps, make sure to ground yourself by touching something metal before handling the SSD.

steps.title: Connect the external enclosure to the laptop.
steps.content: Connect the external enclosure to the laptop. Use a USB cord to connect the external enclosure with the SSD to your laptop. Windows should automatically detect your external SSD. If Windows doesn't detect the SSD drive, press Win+X, then click "Disk Management". Right-click the SSD drive and click "Initialize disk".

steps.title: Close all applications.
steps.content: Close all applications. Before you launch your disk cloning software, close all windows and applications.

steps.title: Click to open your disk cloning software.
steps.content: Click to open your disk cloning software. If you downloaded EaseUS ToDo Backup, go ahead and click it to launch it. You may be asked to enter a license key the first time you launch it. If you are asked to enter a license key, just click "Later".

steps.title: Click Clone.
steps.content: Click Clone . It's at the top of the program, below the icon with two squares stacked on top of each other.

steps.title: Select a source drive and click Next.
steps.content: Select a source drive and click Next . Your source drive is the current drive you have Windows and all your files installed on.

steps.title: Select the SSD as the target drive.
steps.content: Select the SSD as the target drive. The target drive is the drive that you want to clone your current hard drive too.

steps.title: Click Advanced options.
steps.content: Click Advanced options . It's in the lower-left corner of the software window.

steps.title: Check the checkbox next to "Optimize for SSD".
steps.content: Check the checkbox next to "Optimize for SSD". It's in the advanced options in the lower-left corner.

steps.title: Click Proceed.
steps.content: Click Proceed . It's the button with the check mark in the lower-right corner. This will start the cloning process. Allow a couple of hours for the process to complete.

steps.title: Open Start .
steps.content: Open Start . It's the Windows logo in the lower-left corner of the taskbar.

steps.title: Click .
steps.content: Click . It's the power icon on the left-side of the start menu.

steps.title: Click Shut Down.
steps.content: Click Shut Down . It's in the power icon.

steps.title: Disconnect all cords connected to your laptop.
steps.content: Disconnect all cords connected to your laptop. Once your laptop is shut down, disconnect the power cord and all devices connected to the USB ports (including the SSD).

steps.title: Put on EDS wrist straps.
steps.content: Put on EDS wrist straps. If you do not have EDS wrist straps, touch something metal before handling the SSD or the insides of your laptop.

steps.title: Remove the battery.
steps.content: Remove the battery. It's a good idea to remove the battery before proceeding. Press and hold the power button for 5 seconds to drain any charge that is still lingering in your laptop's circuits.

steps.title: Remove access panel.
steps.content: Remove access panel. Use a small Philips screwdriver to remove the access panel. Normally, the access panel is on the bottom of your laptop. If you can't find it, consult the user's manual for your laptop to find the exact location.

steps.title: Remove old hard drive.
steps.content: Remove old hard drive. Lift the hard drive about 45 degrees and pull it out. If you're not sure where the hard drive is located, consult the user's manual for your laptop.

steps.title: Place SSD in the hard drive slot.
steps.content: Place SSD in the hard drive slot. Place the SSD in the same space you removed the old hard drive from.

steps.title: Put the battery and access panel back on.
steps.content: Put the battery and access panel back on. Put the access panel back on and screw it down, and place the battery back in its slot.

steps.title: Boot up your laptop.
steps.content: Boot up your laptop. Re-connect the power cord and press the power button. Your laptop should boot up the same as usual, but much faster.
